title: Advanced Annual Periodization Framework
content:
**Periodization Philosophy**
Periodization is the systematic manipulation of training variables to optimize adaptation while managing fatigue. The goal is arriving at key events with peak fitness AND peak freshness—two competing demands that require careful orchestration.

**Macrocycle Structure (Annual Plan)**

*Phase 1: Transition/Off-Season (3-6 weeks)*
- Purpose: Physical and psychological recovery from race season
- CTL target: Allow decline to 60-70% of peak
- Training: Unstructured, enjoyable activity; cross-training encouraged
- TSS/week: 200-350 (50% of normal)
- Key focus: Address injuries, movement quality, strength foundation
- Mental: Complete detachment from structured training

*Phase 2: General Preparation/Base (10-16 weeks)*
- Purpose: Build aerobic infrastructure and durability
- CTL progression: 3-5 points per week sustainable
- Intensity distribution: 80-85% Zone 1-2, 15-20% Zone 3, minimal Zone 4-5
- Weekly TSS targets by level:
  - Recreational (CTL 40-60): 350-500 TSS/week
  - Competitive age-group (CTL 60-85): 500-700 TSS/week  
  - Serious amateur (CTL 85-110): 700-900 TSS/week
  - Elite (CTL 110+): 900-1200+ TSS/week
- Volume progression: Increase 5-8% weekly for 3 weeks, then recovery week at 60% volume
- Key sessions: Long aerobic (2-4 hours), technique work, strength 2-3x/week
- Avoid: High-intensity work beyond strides; builds fatigue without proportionate fitness at this phase

*Phase 3: Specific Preparation/Build (6-10 weeks)*
- Purpose: Develop race-specific fitness while maintaining aerobic base
- CTL progression: 2-4 points per week (slower than base due to intensity)
- Intensity distribution: 75% Zone 1-2, 10% Zone 3, 15% Zone 4-5
- Key sessions:
  - Threshold intervals: 2x20min at 95-100% FTP, progressing to 2x30min
  - VO2max: 5x4min at 105-115% FTP with 3-4min recovery
  - Race-pace simulations: Practice goal intensity for goal duration segments
- Strength: Reduce to 1-2x/week maintenance, shift to power/plyometrics
- Long sessions: Maintain but don't extend; add race-pace blocks within

*Phase 4: Competition/Race (2-8 weeks depending on calendar)*
- Purpose: Convert fitness to performance through sharpening and racing
- CTL: Maintain or slight decline acceptable
- TSB management: Dip to -10 to -20 between races, recover to +5 to +15 for A-races
- Intensity: High-quality, race-specific; reduce volume not intensity
- Recovery between races: Minimum 10-14 days for A-race level recovery

**Mesocycle Design (3-4 Week Blocks)**
Standard 3:1 or 4:1 loading pattern:
- Week 1: 100% planned load (moderate stress)
- Week 2: 105-110% planned load (highest stress)
- Week 3: 110-115% planned load OR begin recovery
- Week 4 (recovery): 55-65% volume, maintain some intensity

**CTL Building Guidelines**
- Maximum sustainable CTL gain: 5-7 points/week (risks injury above this)
- Optimal: 3-4 points/week allows adaptation without excessive fatigue
- After break/illness: Rebuild at 50% of original CTL gain rate
- CTL decay rate: ~5-7% per week of inactivity

**Individualization Factors**
- Training age: Newer athletes can progress faster initially
- Recovery capacity: Masters athletes may need 4:1 or 2:1 loading ratios
- Life stress: High life stress = reduce training stress proportionally
- Injury history: Previous injuries require more conservative progression in affected areas

title: Race-Specific Taper Protocols
content:
**Taper Science**
Taper reduces fatigue (ATL) while preserving fitness (CTL). Research shows optimal tapers can improve performance 2-6% (Bosquet et al., 2007). The key is reducing volume substantially while maintaining intensity and frequency.

**Marathon Taper Protocol (3 weeks)**

*21 Days Out:*
- Volume: 75-80% of peak week
- Last truly long run: 20-22 miles (or 2.5-3 hours)
- Quality: One marathon-pace session (8-10 miles with 5-6 at MP)
- TSS: 85% of normal week

*14 Days Out:*
- Volume: 55-65% of peak week
- Long run: 13-15 miles easy
- Quality: One session with 4-5 miles at MP
- TSS: 65% of normal week
- Begin carb considerations (don't deplete)

*7 Days Out:*
- Volume: 35-45% of peak week
- Long run: 8-10 miles easy (6 days out)
- Quality: 2-3 miles at MP within easy run (5 days out)
- TSS: 40-45% of normal week

*Final 3 Days:*
- Day -3: 30-40 min easy + 4-6 strides
- Day -2: 20-30 min very easy OR rest
- Day -1: 15-20 min shakeout + 4 strides, or complete rest

*TSB Target Race Day: +10 to +20*
- Below +5: Likely still fatigued
- Above +25: May feel flat, possible detraining

**Half Marathon Taper (10-14 days)**

*10-14 Days Out:*
- Volume: 70% of normal
- Last long run: 12-14 miles
- One quality session: 6 miles with 3-4 at HM pace

*7 Days Out:*
- Volume: 50-55% of normal
- Long run: 8-10 miles easy
- Quality: 4 miles with 2 at HM pace

*3 Days Out:*
- Day -3: 40 min easy + strides
- Day -2: 25-30 min easy
- Day -1: 15-20 min + 4 strides

*TSB Target: +8 to +15*

**Olympic/Sprint Triathlon Taper (7-10 days)**

*10 Days Out:*
- Volume: 65-70%
- Last brick workout: 90min bike + 25min run
- One quality swim session

*5-7 Days Out:*
- Volume: 45-55%
- Short race-pace openers in each sport
- Brick: 45min bike + 15min run at race pace

*2-3 Days Out:*
- Very short openers in each sport (15-20 min)
- Strides/accelerations to maintain neuromuscular readiness

**Ironman Taper (3 weeks)**

*21 Days Out:*
- Volume: 70-75%
- Last long ride: 5-6 hours with nutrition practice
- Last long run: 2-2.5 hours

*14 Days Out:*
- Volume: 50-55%
- Moderate brick (3hr bike + 45min run)
- Focus on feel-good sessions

*7 Days Out:*
- Volume: 30-40%
- Short race-pace touches in each sport
- Travel and logistics focus

*TSB Target: +15 to +25*

**Taper Troubleshooting**

*'Taper Tantrum' (feeling terrible during taper):*
- Normal phenomenon: reduced endorphins, glycogen supersaturation feels 'heavy'
- Don't panic-train; trust the process
- Light movement helps more than complete rest
- Usually resolves 24-48 hours before race

*Feeling Flat on Race Day:*
- Possible over-taper (too long or too aggressive)
- Next time: Shorter taper or maintain more intensity
- Can't fix on race day; execute best effort with current state

*Still Feeling Tired:*
- Possible under-taper or accumulated fatigue from build
- May need extra day or two of rest
- Future: Build in more recovery weeks during preparation

title: Advanced PMC Interpretation and Application
content:
**Deep Understanding of TSS**

TSS (Training Stress Score) quantifies the physiological cost of a workout normalized to threshold effort:
- TSS = (duration in seconds × IF² × 100) / 3600
- IF (Intensity Factor) = normalized power / FTP
- 100 TSS = 1 hour at FTP (by definition)

**TSS Calibration by Workout Type:**
- Recovery ride (IF 0.55): ~30 TSS/hour
- Endurance ride (IF 0.65-0.75): ~45-55 TSS/hour
- Tempo ride (IF 0.80-0.85): ~65-75 TSS/hour
- Sweet spot (IF 0.88-0.93): ~80-90 TSS/hour
- Threshold intervals (IF 0.95-1.0): ~90-100 TSS/hour
- VO2max intervals (IF 1.0-1.1): ~100-120 TSS/hour
- Races (IF 1.0+): 100+ TSS/hour

**Running/Swimming TSS Equivalents:**
- rTSS: Based on pace vs threshold pace (or heart rate if no pace)
- sTSS: Based on CSS (Critical Swim Speed)
- These are estimates; power-based TSS is more accurate

**CTL (Chronic Training Load) - Fitness**

*Mathematical Definition:*
- 42-day exponentially weighted moving average of TSS
- Yesterday's CTL contributes ~97.6% to today's; today's TSS contributes ~2.4%
- CTL(today) = CTL(yesterday) × 0.976 + TSS(today) × 0.024

*Interpretation by Level:*
- CTL 30-50: Recreational fitness
- CTL 50-70: Regular exerciser, capable of sprint/Olympic tri
- CTL 70-90: Competitive age-grouper, marathon capable
- CTL 90-110: Serious amateur, Ironman capable
- CTL 110-130: Elite age-group, national-level performance
- CTL 130+: Professional-level training load

*CTL Building Rates:*
- Aggressive: 5-7 CTL/week (high injury/burnout risk)
- Optimal: 3-5 CTL/week (sustainable with good recovery)
- Conservative: 2-3 CTL/week (lower risk, slower progress)
- After illness/break: Maximum 2-3 CTL/week initially

**ATL (Acute Training Load) - Fatigue**

*Mathematical Definition:*
- 7-day exponentially weighted moving average of TSS
- Responds quickly to training changes
- ATL(today) = ATL(yesterday) × 0.857 + TSS(today) × 0.143

*Interpretation:*
- ATL >> CTL: Recent training much harder than normal (overreaching)
- ATL ≈ CTL: Maintenance phase
- ATL << CTL: Tapering or undertrained recently

**TSB (Training Stress Balance) - Form**

*Formula:* TSB = CTL - ATL

*Ranges and Meaning:*
- TSB < -30: Extreme fatigue, overreaching territory (planned or unplanned)
- TSB -20 to -30: Deep fatigue, appropriate for hard training blocks
- TSB -10 to -20: Productive training, moderate fatigue
- TSB -5 to -10: Light training load
- TSB 0 to +5: Maintenance, transition phase
- TSB +5 to +15: Fresh, ready for quality efforts or racing
- TSB +15 to +25: Peak freshness for A-races
- TSB > +25: Risk of detraining, feeling flat

**Advanced PMC Applications**

*Predicting Race Readiness:*
- Model various taper scenarios to find optimal TSB
- Individual variation: some perform best at +10, others at +20
- Track personal race performances vs TSB to find your sweet spot

*Planning Training Blocks:*
- Overreach blocks: Drive TSB to -25 to -35 for 1-2 weeks, then recover
- Recovery blocks: Bring TSB to +5 to +10
- Build: Maintain TSB between -10 and -20

*ACWR (Acute:Chronic Workload Ratio):*
- ACWR = ATL / CTL
- Safe zone: 0.8 to 1.3
- Injury risk increases significantly above 1.5
- Below 0.8 indicates detraining

**PMC Limitations**
- Doesn't account for workout type (intervals vs steady state)
- Doesn't capture training quality or execution
- Individual recovery rates vary
- Life stress not captured
- Use alongside HRV and subjective metrics

title: Precision Interval Prescription
content:
**Interval Design Principles**

Effective intervals target specific physiological systems with appropriate stress-recovery balance. The art is prescribing the minimum effective dose for maximum adaptation.

**VO2max Intervals (Zone 5)**

*Physiological Target:* Maximize time at >90% VO2max to drive aerobic ceiling higher

*Optimal Protocols:*
- Classic: 5×4min at 105-115% FTP, 3-4min recovery
- Billat 30/30: 30sec hard (110-120% FTP) / 30sec float (65% FTP) × 12-20 reps
- Descending: 5min, 4min, 3min, 2min at 105-120% FTP, equal recovery
- Tabata variation: 8×20sec all-out / 10sec rest (anaerobic + VO2max)

*Total Work Target:* 12-20 minutes at VO2max intensity per session
*Frequency:* 1-2× per week during build phase
*Recovery Need:* 48-72 hours before next hard session

*Execution Cues:*
- Hard but not maximal; could do one more rep at end
- Breathing very hard but controlled
- Power should be sustainable across all intervals (not dying on last one)

**Threshold Intervals (Zone 4)**

*Physiological Target:* Raise lactate threshold, improve power at threshold

*Optimal Protocols:*
- Classic: 2×20min at 95-100% FTP, 5-10min recovery
- Progression: 3×15min → 2×20min → 2×25min → 1×45min over weeks
- Criss-cross: 20min alternating 2min at 90% / 2min at 105% FTP
- Over-unders: 10-15min with 2min at 105% / 2min at 95% FTP alternating

*Total Work Target:* 30-60 minutes at threshold per session
*Frequency:* 1-2× per week
*Recovery Need:* 36-48 hours

*Execution Cues:*
- 'Comfortably hard' - could speak in short sentences
- Should feel achievable but demanding
- Breathing elevated but controlled

**Sweet Spot Intervals (Zone 3-4 boundary)**

*Physiological Target:* Maximum training stimulus per unit of fatigue

*Optimal Protocols:*
- Standard: 3×15min at 88-93% FTP, 5min recovery
- Extended: 2×30min at 88-90% FTP, 10min recovery
- Time-crunched: 1×45-60min at 88-90% FTP (continuous)

*Total Work Target:* 40-90 minutes per session
*Frequency:* 2-3× per week sustainable
*Recovery Need:* 24-36 hours

*Why Sweet Spot Works:*
- 90% of threshold benefit at 50% of the fatigue cost
- Ideal for time-limited athletes
- Can accumulate high volume of quality work

**Tempo Intervals (Zone 3)**

*Physiological Target:* Aerobic endurance, fat oxidation, muscular endurance

*Optimal Protocols:*
- Continuous: 45-90min at 76-87% FTP
- Blocks: 3×20min at 80-87% FTP with 5min easy
- Long ride integration: 2-3× 20-30min tempo blocks within endurance ride

*Frequency:* 2-3× per week, often combined with endurance
*Recovery Need:* 24 hours

**Anaerobic Capacity (Zone 6)**

*Physiological Target:* Increase anaerobic work capacity, tolerance to high lactate

*Protocols:*
- Short: 8-12× 30sec at 130-150% FTP, 30sec recovery
- Medium: 6-8× 1min at 120-130% FTP, 2min recovery
- Long anaerobic: 4-5× 2min at 115-125% FTP, 3min recovery

*Total Work Target:* 6-15 minutes at anaerobic intensity
*Frequency:* 1× per week maximum; very fatiguing
*Recovery Need:* 72+ hours

**Neuromuscular/Sprint (Zone 7)**

*Physiological Target:* Peak power, neuromuscular coordination, fast-twitch recruitment

*Protocols:*
- Standing starts: 6-8× 15sec maximal from slow roll, full recovery
- Flying sprints: 6-8× 10-15sec maximal from moderate pace, 3-5min recovery
- Race simulation sprints: Practice race-specific power demands

*Frequency:* 1-2× per week, low total stress
*Placement:* After warm-up, before fatigue accumulates

**Running-Specific Intervals**

*VO2max (equivalent to cycling Zone 5):*
- 5-6× 1000m at 3K-5K pace, 2-3min jog recovery
- 6-8× 800m at 3K pace, 90sec-2min recovery
- 10-12× 400m at mile pace, 60-90sec recovery

*Threshold:*
- Tempo run: 20-40min continuous at threshold pace (half marathon to marathon pace)
- Cruise intervals: 3-4× 10min at threshold pace, 2min jog
- Progression run: Start easy, finish final 20-30% at threshold

*Recovery Between Running Intervals:*
- Jog, don't walk (maintains running mechanics)
- Recovery pace: 2-3 min/mile slower than interval pace

title: Polarized Training Model and 80/20 Distribution
content:
**The Polarized Training Model**

Research on elite endurance athletes consistently shows they spend 75-85% of training time at low intensity and 15-25% at high intensity, with minimal time at moderate ('tempo') intensity. This contradicts the intuition that 'no pain, no gain.'

**Evidence Base**
- Seiler et al. (2006): Norwegian cross-country skiers, 83% low / 17% high
- Billat et al. (2003): Kenyan marathon runners, 85% low / 15% high
- Studies comparing polarized vs threshold training show polarized produces equal or better results with less burnout (Stöggl & Sperlich, 2014)

**Why Polarized Works**

*Low Intensity (Zone 1-2) Adaptations:*
- Mitochondrial biogenesis
- Capillary density increase
- Fat oxidation improvement
- Aerobic enzyme enhancement
- Mental recovery while training
- Sustainable volume accumulation

*High Intensity (Zone 4-5) Adaptations:*
- VO2max improvement
- Lactate threshold elevation
- Neuromuscular power
- Race-specific fitness
- Psychological toughness

*Why Avoid the Middle (Zone 3):*
- Too hard to accumulate volume
- Too easy to drive high-end adaptations
- Creates most fatigue per unit of adaptation
- 'Black hole' training: feels productive but isn't optimal

**Practical Implementation**

*Defining Zones for 80/20:*
- Low: Below VT1 (ventilatory threshold 1), conversational pace
  - Can speak in full sentences
  - Heart rate typically <75-80% max
  - Power <75% FTP
- High: Above VT2 (ventilatory threshold 2), hard effort
  - Cannot speak more than a few words
  - Heart rate >88-90% max
  - Power >90% FTP

*Weekly Structure Example (10 hours/week):*
- 8 hours easy (Zone 1-2)
- 2 hours hard (Zone 4-5)
- Minimize Zone 3 'no man's land'

*Common Mistake: Easy Days Too Hard*
- Most age-groupers run Zone 3 on 'easy' days
- Monitor heart rate on easy days
- Should feel genuinely easy, almost too easy
- Ego check: slow down

**Polarized vs Pyramidal vs Threshold-Based**

*Polarized:*
- ~80% low, ~15-20% high, ~0-5% moderate
- Best for: High volume athletes, avoiding burnout

*Pyramidal:*
- ~75% low, ~15% moderate, ~10% high
- More Zone 3 work than polarized
- Best for: Middle-distance events, time-crunched athletes

*Threshold-Focused:*
- ~65% low, ~25% moderate, ~10% high
- Heavy sweet spot and tempo work
- Best for: Time-crunched (<8 hrs/week), responds well to threshold

**Individual Response**
- Some athletes thrive on more threshold work
- Monitor: If performance plateaus despite training, try more polarized approach
- Age-group athletes often benefit from polarized model due to recovery limitations

**Tracking Distribution**
- Use training software to calculate time-in-zone
- Review monthly distribution, not just weekly
- Heart rate zones more practical than power for this analysis
- Common finding: Athletes think they're 80/20 but are actually 60/30/10

title: Advanced Running Training Systems
content:
**Running Training Philosophy**

Running training must balance the need for aerobic development, neuromuscular speed, and structural adaptation while managing the high impact forces (2.5-3× bodyweight per stride).

**Mileage Frameworks**

*Weekly Mileage Guidelines by Race Distance:*
- 5K specialist: 30-70 miles/week
- 10K specialist: 40-80 miles/week
- Half marathon: 40-70 miles/week (recreational) to 80-100+ (competitive)
- Marathon: 40-55 miles/week (finish focus) to 70-120+ miles/week (competitive)
- Ultra: Highly variable; time on feet matters more than miles

*Building Mileage Safely:*
- Increase max 10% per week (5% for injury-prone runners)
- Every 4th week: Drop to 60-70% for recovery
- When adding mileage, add easy miles only
- Add one run per week before extending runs
- Takes 6-12 months to safely add 20+ miles/week

**Long Run Programming**

*Purpose:* Aerobic endurance, fat oxidation, mental fortitude, glycogen depletion adaptation

*Duration by Goal:*
- 5K-10K: 60-90 min
- Half marathon: 90-120 min
- Marathon: 2:30-3:30 (cap at 3:30 or 22 miles, whichever comes first)
- Ultra: Build to race-specific duration gradually

*Intensity:*
- Base phase: All easy, conversational
- Build phase: Add progression elements:
  - Final 20-30% at marathon pace
  - Or: 2-3× 20min at marathon pace within long run
  - Fast-finish long run: Final 4-6 miles at progressively faster pace

*Recovery:*
- Long runs create significant fatigue
- Following day: Rest or very easy 20-30min
- 2 days after: Can resume normal training

**Key Workout Types**

*Tempo/Threshold Runs:*
- Classic tempo: 20-40min at threshold pace (roughly half marathon pace for most)
- Cruise intervals: 3-4× 10min at threshold, 90sec jog recovery
- Tempo progression: 15min easy → 20-30min tempo → 15min easy
- Frequency: 1× per week in build phase

*Interval Training:*

VO2max Development:
- 1000m repeats: 5-6× at 3K-5K pace, 2-3min recovery
- 800m repeats: 6-8× at 3K pace, 90sec-2min recovery  
- Ladders: 400-800-1200-1600-1200-800-400 at 3K-5K pace

Speed Development:
- 400m repeats: 10-12× at mile pace, 60-90sec recovery
- 200m repeats: 12-16× at 800m-mile pace, 45-60sec recovery
- Hill sprints: 8-10× 10-15sec maximal uphill, walk down recovery

*Marathon-Specific Workouts:*
- MP tempo: 8-14 miles at marathon pace
- Yasso 800s: 10× 800m in time equal to goal marathon time (e.g., 3:30 marathon = 3:30 per 800)
- Simulator: 16-18 miles with final 10-12 at MP
- Cutdown long run: 20 miles starting easy, last 6-8 at MP

**Strides**

*What:* 20-30 second controlled accelerations to near-sprint, with full recovery
*Why:* Neuromuscular activation, running economy, form maintenance
*When:* 4-6× after easy runs, 2-3× per week
*How:* Accelerate smoothly over 10 sec, hold near-max 10 sec, decelerate. Walk 60-90 sec between.

**Double Days**

*Purpose:* Increase volume without extending single run duration
*Structure:* Main session AM or PM, easy 30-45min opposite time
*When to Consider:* 
- Mileage exceeds 60-70 miles/week
- Can't recover from single long runs
- Time constraints
*Typical Split:* 60-70% mileage in primary run, 30-40% in secondary

**Running-Specific Recovery**
- Running creates more muscle damage than cycling
- Minimum 48 hours between hard running sessions
- Easy runs: Truly easy (60-90 sec/mile slower than threshold)
- Cross-train on recovery days if desired (bike, swim, elliptical)

title: Advanced Cycling Training Systems
content:
**Power-Based Training Fundamentals**

Power meters provide objective, instantaneous feedback that transforms cycling training precision.

**FTP Testing Protocols**

*20-Minute Test:*
- Warm-up: 20min including 3× 1min hard efforts
- Test: 20 minutes, maximum sustainable effort
- FTP = 20-min power × 0.95
- Best for: Most athletes, field testing

*Ramp Test:*
- Start at ~50% estimated FTP
- Increase 20-25W every minute until failure
- FTP = 75% of final minute power
- Best for: Quick assessment, less psychological stress

*8-Minute Test:*
- Two 8-minute max efforts with 10min recovery
- FTP = average of both × 0.90
- Best for: Athletes who struggle with 20min pacing

*Retest Frequency:* Every 4-8 weeks during build phase; FTP can change 2-5% per month

**Power Zones (Coggan Model)**

*Zone 1 - Active Recovery (<55% FTP):*
- Purpose: Recovery, blood flow promotion
- Feeling: Very easy, can talk indefinitely
- RPE: 1-2/10

*Zone 2 - Endurance (55-75% FTP):*
- Purpose: Aerobic base, fat oxidation, volume accumulation
- Feeling: Easy to moderate, conversational
- RPE: 3-4/10
- Time: Unlimited; foundation of training

*Zone 3 - Tempo (76-90% FTP):*
- Purpose: Muscular endurance, aerobic capacity
- Feeling: Moderate, requires focus
- RPE: 5-6/10
- Time: 20min to 2+ hours

*Zone 4 - Threshold (91-105% FTP):*
- Purpose: Raise FTP, lactate tolerance
- Feeling: Hard, sustainable with concentration
- RPE: 7-8/10
- Time: 8-30 minutes in intervals

*Zone 5 - VO2max (106-120% FTP):*
- Purpose: Increase VO2max ceiling
- Feeling: Very hard, breathing very labored
- RPE: 8-9/10
- Time: 3-8 minutes in intervals

*Zone 6 - Anaerobic (121-150% FTP):*
- Purpose: Anaerobic capacity, high-power repeatability
- Feeling: Extremely hard, unsustainable
- RPE: 9-10/10
- Time: 30sec to 3 minutes

*Zone 7 - Neuromuscular (>150% FTP):*
- Purpose: Peak power, sprint ability
- Feeling: Maximum effort
- Time: <30 seconds

**Cycling-Specific Workouts**

*Endurance Development:*
- Long ride: 3-6 hours at Zone 2 with terrain variation
- Tempo blocks: 2-3× 20-30min Zone 3 within endurance ride

*Threshold Development:*
- 2×20 min at 95-100% FTP, 10min recovery (gold standard)
- Over-unders: 2min at 105% / 2min at 95% × 4-5, 10min recovery, repeat
- Progression: Start with 2×15min, build to 2×30min over 8 weeks

*VO2max Development:*
- 5×4min at 108-112% FTP, 4min recovery
- 6×3min at 110-115% FTP, 3min recovery
- Tabata: 8×20sec max / 10sec easy (anaerobic + VO2max)

*Sweet Spot:*
- 3×20min at 88-93% FTP, 5min recovery
- 2×40min at 88-90% FTP
- Time-crunched option: 1×60min continuous at 88% FTP

**Indoor vs Outdoor Considerations**

*Indoor Training Benefits:*
- No coasting, constant load = higher training density
- Weather independent
- Safe for high-intensity work
- Time efficient

*Indoor Adjustments:*
- RPE feels 5-10% harder due to heat, boredom, no wind
- Consider reducing FTP target by 5-10% indoors, or use indoor-specific FTP
- Cooling is critical: multiple fans, minimal clothing
- Hydration needs increase significantly
- Sessions >90min challenging psychologically

*TSS Equivalence:* Indoor TSS often undercounts total stress due to thermal load

**Specificity for Event Types**

*Road Racing:*
- Variable power, repeated surges
- Include over-unders, attack simulations
- Group ride practice essential

*Time Trial:*
- Steady-state power, pacing
- Threshold work emphasis
- Practice race position and power

*Climbing:*
- 10-20min efforts at threshold+
- Include steep gradient simulation (low cadence, high force)

*Criterium:*
- Repeated high-power efforts
- Sprinting out of corners
- Anaerobic capacity focus

title: Triathlon-Specific Training Integration
content:
**Multi-Sport Training Philosophy**

Triathlon training requires balancing three sports while managing total stress load. The challenge is not just fitness—it's optimizing limited time and recovery capacity across disciplines.

**Training Volume Distribution by Race Distance**

*Sprint Triathlon (750m/20K/5K):*
- Weekly hours: 6-10
- Swim: 20-25% (1.5-2 hrs)
- Bike: 40-45% (3-4 hrs)
- Run: 30-35% (2-3 hrs)
- Focus: Speed in all three, transitions

*Olympic Triathlon (1500m/40K/10K):*
- Weekly hours: 8-14
- Swim: 20% (2-3 hrs)
- Bike: 45% (4-6 hrs)
- Run: 30% (3-4 hrs)
- Strength: 5% (1 hr)
- Focus: Threshold development, race-pace work

*Half Ironman (70.3):*
- Weekly hours: 10-18
- Swim: 15-20% (2-3 hrs)
- Bike: 45-50% (5-8 hrs)
- Run: 25-30% (3-5 hrs)
- Strength: 5% (1 hr)
- Focus: Endurance, bike strength, run off bike

*Ironman (140.6):*
- Weekly hours: 14-25+
- Swim: 12-18% (2-4 hrs)
- Bike: 50-55% (8-14 hrs)
- Run: 25-30% (4-7 hrs)
- Strength: Maintenance only
- Focus: Volume, muscular endurance, nutrition execution

**Brick Workouts: Science and Application**

*Physiological Purpose:*
- Neuromuscular adaptation to bike-run transition
- Learn pacing off the bike
- Mental preparation for run sensations
- Nutrition practice

*Brick Progressions:*

Early Season:
- Short brick: 45-60min bike (Z2) + 15-20min run (easy)
- Purpose: Introduce brick sensation
- Frequency: 1× per week

Build Phase:
- Medium brick: 90min bike (with tempo) + 30-40min run (with some pace)
- Long brick: 3-4hr bike + 45-60min run
- Race simulation: Race-effort bike + race-pace run segments
- Frequency: 1-2× per week

*Brick Execution Tips:*
- First 5-10 min of run always feels awkward—don't panic
- Start run 10-15 sec/mile slower than goal pace, settle in
- Cadence often helps: Higher leg turnover, shorter stride initially
- Practice quick transition in training

**Swim Training for Triathletes**

*Swim Limiters vs Fitness:*
- Most triathletes limited by technique, not fitness
- Spend 25-30% of swim time on drills until technically proficient
- Video analysis extremely valuable

*Key Technique Points:*
- Body position: Float horizontal, head neutral
- Catch: Early vertical forearm, 'grab' water
- Pull: High elbow, push through to hip
- Rotation: 45-60 degrees, drives from hips
- Kick: Small, from hips, for balance (not propulsion in long-course)

*CSS (Critical Swim Speed):*
- Threshold equivalent for swimming
- Test: Time 400m and 200m best effort
- CSS pace = (400m time - 200m time) / 2 (gives pace per 100m difference)
- Train at CSS pace for threshold development

*Sample Swim Workouts (3000m Total):*

Threshold Focus:
- 400 warm-up, 4×100 build
- 5×200 at CSS + 5sec rest, 20sec rest
- 4×100 descend 1-4
- 200 cool-down

Speed Focus:
- 400 warm-up with drills
- 8×50 at 90% max, 15sec rest
- 4×100 at CSS, 10sec rest
- 8×25 sprint, 20sec rest
- 300 cool-down

**Weekly Structure Examples**

*Olympic Distance (10 hours/week):*
- Monday: Rest
- Tuesday: AM Swim (60min), PM Run intervals (45min)
- Wednesday: Bike trainer (75min with intensity)
- Thursday: AM Swim (45min), PM Run easy (40min)
- Friday: Rest or easy spin (30min)
- Saturday: Long bike (2-2.5hrs) with brick run (20min)
- Sunday: Long run (75min)

*Half Ironman (14 hours/week):*
- Monday: Rest or yoga
- Tuesday: AM Swim (60min), PM Run intervals (50min)
- Wednesday: Bike (90min with sweet spot or threshold)
- Thursday: AM Swim (60min), PM Run easy (50min)
- Friday: Bike easy (60min) or rest
- Saturday: Long bike (3.5-4hrs) with brick run (30-40min)
- Sunday: Long run (90-105min)

**Race-Specific Considerations**

*Open Water Swimming:*
- Practice sighting every 6-10 strokes
- Draft off other swimmers (legal, saves 20%+ energy)
- Wetsuit practice: changes buoyancy and stroke
- Start practice: Beach starts, treading water starts

*Transition Optimization:*
- T1 (swim-bike): Target <2min for age-groupers
- T2 (bike-run): Target <1.5min
- Practice in training: Set up transition area, rehearse
- Elastic laces, flying mount/dismount save significant time

title: Strength Training for Endurance Performance
content:
**Evidence for Strength Training in Endurance**

Research consistently shows strength training improves endurance performance through:
- Improved economy (2-8% improvement in running economy)
- Delayed fatigue via recruitment of fatigue-resistant motor units
- Injury prevention (up to 50% reduction in overuse injuries)
- Preservation of muscle mass (especially important for masters)
- Improved force production for hills, surges, finishing kicks

**Periodized Strength for Endurance Athletes**

*Off-Season/Base (8-12 weeks):*
- Frequency: 2-3× per week
- Focus: Hypertrophy and structural adaptation
- Sets/Reps: 3-4 sets × 8-12 reps
- Intensity: Moderate (65-75% 1RM), focus on form
- Volume: Higher (building foundation)

*Build Phase (6-8 weeks):*
- Frequency: 2× per week
- Focus: Maximal strength
- Sets/Reps: 3-5 sets × 4-6 reps
- Intensity: Heavy (80-90% 1RM)
- Volume: Moderate (maintain while building strength)

*Race Phase (4-8 weeks):*
- Frequency: 1-2× per week (maintenance)
- Focus: Power and maintenance
- Sets/Reps: 2-3 sets × 3-5 reps (strength) or 2-3 × 6-8 explosive (power)
- Intensity: Moderate-heavy but reduced volume
- Add plyometrics for power transfer

*Taper (1-3 weeks):*
- Frequency: 0-1× per week
- If lifting: Very light, movement maintenance only
- Stop heavy lifting 7-10 days before A-race

**Key Exercises by Sport**

*Running:*

Primary:
- Squat (back, front, or goblet): Hip and knee extension
- Romanian deadlift: Posterior chain, hip hinge
- Single-leg exercises (step-ups, lunges, Bulgarian split squat): Unilateral strength, balance
- Calf raises (straight and bent knee): Propulsion, injury prevention

Accessory:
- Hip abduction/adduction: Lateral stability
- Core: Planks, dead bugs, Pallof press
- Hip flexor strengthening: Knee drive

Running-Specific:
- Box jumps: Power transfer
- Bounding: Plyometric running strength
- Single-leg hops: Running-specific power

*Cycling:*

Primary:
- Squat variations: Hip/knee extension power
- Leg press: Similar pattern to pedaling
- Romanian deadlift: Posterior chain engagement
- Step-ups: Single-leg power

Accessory:
- Core stability (resisting rotation on bike)
- Upper back (comfort in aero position)
- Hip flexors (top of pedal stroke)

Cycling-Specific:
- Single-leg squats: Addresses bilateral deficit
- Low-cadence, high-force trainer intervals

*Swimming:*

Primary:
- Lat pulldown / Pull-ups: Pull phase power
- Rows (cable, dumbbell, TRX): Horizontal pulling
- Shoulder press: Recovery phase, overhead stability
- Rotator cuff: Injury prevention critical

Core:
- Streamline holds (hollow body)
- Rotation stability (cable woodchops)
- Flutter kick holds

**Sample Strength Workouts**

*Full Body for Endurance Athletes (45-60 min):*

Warm-up: 5-10min dynamic movement

Primary (pick 3-4):
- Goblet squat: 3×10
- Romanian deadlift: 3×8
- Bulgarian split squat: 3×8 each leg
- Bench press or push-ups: 3×10
- Bent-over row: 3×10

Accessory (pick 2-3):
- Single-leg calf raise: 2×15
- Pallof press: 2×12 each side
- Side plank: 2×30sec each side

Cool-down: 5-10min mobility

*Power-Focused Session (30-40 min):*
- Box jumps: 3×5 (full recovery)
- Medicine ball slams: 3×8
- Jump squats: 3×6
- Bounding: 3×20m
- Plyo push-ups: 3×6

**Integration with Endurance Training**

*Scheduling:*
- Don't lift heavy before key workouts
- Option 1: Lift after hard endurance sessions (same day, combined stress)
- Option 2: Lift on easy days, 24+ hours before hard session
- Never lift heavy the day before key workouts or races

*Managing Fatigue:*
- Initial adaptation phase: 2-4 weeks of extra fatigue, then normalizes
- Reduce endurance volume slightly when starting strength program
- If legs are trashed for key workouts, reduce strength volume

*Signs Strength Is Helping:*
- Improved power on hills
- Better finishing kick
- Fewer aches and injuries
- Same speed at lower perceived effort

title: Environmental Training: Heat and Altitude Adaptation
content:
**Heat Acclimatization**

*Physiological Adaptations:*
- Expanded plasma volume (improved cardiovascular stability)
- Earlier and more dilute sweating (better cooling)
- Reduced core temperature at given intensity
- Lower heart rate at given intensity
- Reduced perceived exertion
- Time to adapt: 10-14 days for full adaptation

*Heat Acclimatization Protocol:*

Phase 1 (Days 1-5):
- Duration: 30-60 min in heat daily
- Intensity: Easy (Zone 1-2)
- Purpose: Initial plasma volume expansion
- Caution: Monitor for excessive heat stress

Phase 2 (Days 6-10):
- Duration: 60-90 min in heat
- Intensity: Can add moderate efforts
- Sweating response improving
- Heart rate drift reducing

Phase 3 (Days 11-14):
- Duration: Race-specific sessions
- Intensity: Can include quality work
- Full adaptation achieved for most athletes

*Heat Training When Not in Hot Climate:*
- Post-workout sauna: 20-30min at 80-100°C, 2-3× per week
- Hot baths: 30-40min at 40°C post-workout
- Train at hottest part of day (carefully)
- Indoor trainer without cooling
- Maintain hydration and safety

*Racing in Heat:*
- Pre-cool: Ice vest, cold towels, slushie before start
- Pacing: Start conservative, allow faster adaptation
- Hydration: Higher sodium intake (500-1000mg/hour)
- Adjust expectations: 1-3% performance decrement typical
- Monitor: Headache, nausea, confusion = stop immediately

**Altitude Training**

*Physiological Responses:*
- Immediate: Increased ventilation, heart rate, perceived effort
- Short-term (1-3 weeks): EPO release, beginning of red blood cell production
- Long-term (3-4 weeks): Increased hemoglobin mass, improved oxygen delivery
- Detraining: Benefits persist 2-4 weeks after return to sea level

*Classic Live High, Train Low (LHTL):*
- Live: 2000-2500m (6500-8200ft) altitude
- Sleep: Minimum 12-14 hours/day at altitude
- Train hard: Below 1200m (4000ft) where oxygen allows full intensity
- Duration: Minimum 3-4 weeks for significant adaptation
- Evidence: 1-3% performance improvement in elite athletes

*Altitude Camps (Live High, Train High):*
- Both living and training at altitude
- More accessible than LHTL
- Compromise: Can't train at full intensity
- Duration: 3-4 weeks minimum
- Intensity: Reduce by 10-15% initially, gradually normalize

*Altitude Tents/Masks (Sleep High):*
- Simulated altitude while sleeping at home
- Target altitude: 2500-3000m equivalent
- Duration: 8-10 hours per night, 4+ weeks
- Evidence: Mixed; some benefit, less than real altitude
- Caution: Sleep quality may suffer

*Altitude Training Precautions:*
- Adequate iron stores essential (ferritin >30-50 ng/mL)
- Increase hydration (fluid loss higher at altitude)
- Reduce training load first 3-5 days
- Monitor for altitude sickness: headache, nausea, sleep disruption
- Descend if symptoms severe

*Racing at Altitude (Coming from Sea Level):*
- Arrive either <24 hours before OR 2+ weeks before
- 1-10 days = worst performance (some adaptation, not complete)
- VO2max reduced ~3% per 1000m above 1200m
- Endurance events most affected; short sprints less so
- Pacing: Start more conservative, adjust expectations

*Racing at Sea Level After Altitude:*
- Peak performance window: Days 2-21 after descent
- Individual variation: Some peak immediately, others at 7-14 days
- Track personal response over multiple camps
- Plan racing calendar around altitude blocks

title: Advanced Training Data Analysis
content:
**Beyond TSS: Meaningful Metrics**

*Normalized Power (NP):*
- What: 30-second rolling average raised to 4th power, then averaged, then rooted
- Why: Accounts for physiological cost of variability
- Use: Comparing efforts with different patterns
- Example: 200W average vs 200W NP—NP effort was harder

*Intensity Factor (IF):*
- What: NP / FTP
- Interpretation:
  - IF < 0.75: Recovery/endurance
  - IF 0.75-0.85: Tempo/aerobic endurance
  - IF 0.85-0.95: Threshold race or hard training
  - IF 0.95-1.05: TT effort, sustainable 45-60min
  - IF > 1.05: Short race or intervals (not sustainable)

*Variability Index (VI):*
- What: NP / Average Power
- Interpretation:
  - VI ≈ 1.0: Very steady (time trial)
  - VI 1.0-1.05: Moderately variable (rolling course)
  - VI > 1.1: Highly variable (criterium, mountain stage)
- Use: Assess pacing execution, course demands

*Efficiency Factor (EF):*
- What: NP / Average Heart Rate
- Use: Track aerobic fitness improvements
- Increasing EF at same RPE = improving fitness
- Compare only similar workouts and conditions

*Decoupling:*
- What: Heart rate drift relative to power during steady effort
- Calculation: (2nd half HR / 2nd half power) vs (1st half HR / 1st half power)
- <5% decoupling: Good aerobic fitness
- >5% decoupling: Aerobic system still developing OR pacing/fueling issue
- Use: Assess aerobic base readiness

**Running Metrics**

*Running Power:*
- Similar concept to cycling power
- Platform-specific (Stryd, Garmin, etc.)
- Useful for: Pacing on hills, wind, heat adjustment
- Limitation: Less standardized than cycling power

*Running Dynamics:*
- Cadence: 170-185 spm typical for distance running
  - Higher cadence often correlates with lower injury risk
  - Don't force changes; usually improves naturally with speed
- Ground contact time: 200-300ms typical
  - Lower = more efficient (but don't obsess)
- Vertical oscillation: Lower is generally more efficient
  - Focus on 'running over the ground, not up and down'
- Left-right balance: Ideally 50/50, but 48-52% common

**Heart Rate Analysis**

*Heart Rate Variability (HRV):*
- See dedicated HRV section for detailed protocols
- Key for readiness assessment

*Resting Heart Rate Trends:*
- Elevated RHR (>5bpm above normal): Accumulated fatigue, illness onset, or stress
- Gradually declining RHR over months: Improved cardiovascular fitness
- Measure: Same conditions daily (morning, before rising)

*Heart Rate Drift:*
- HR rising during steady-state effort indicates:
  - Cardiovascular drift (thermal, normal in heat)
  - Dehydration
  - Fading fitness (glycogen depletion)
  - Inadequate aerobic base
- Acceptable drift: <5% over 60-90min steady effort

**Detecting Overtraining Through Data**

*Red Flags:*
- Power declining at same RPE and HR
- HR failing to rise during intervals (parasympathetic overtraining)
- HR abnormally high at all intensities (sympathetic overtraining)
- HRV consistently 15%+ below baseline
- Resting HR elevated 5+ bpm for 3+ consecutive days
- Sleep quality declining per tracking data

*What to Do:*
- Single day of abnormal data: Note and continue, monitor closely
- 2-3 days: Reduce intensity, extra recovery
- 4+ days: Consider rest block (3-7 days easy or off)

**Longitudinal Analysis**

*Season-Over-Season Comparison:*
- CTL at same point in training year
- FTP progression
- Training volume (hours, TSS)
- Injury frequency
- Race results at similar fitness levels

*Key Questions:*
- Am I fitter than this time last year?
- Am I training more or less? Harder or easier?
- What worked? What didn't?
- Where were injury/illness setbacks?

*Data Hygiene:*
- Ensure consistent equipment (same power meter, same HR strap)
- Note conditions (temperature, elevation, indoor/outdoor)
- Record subjective factors (sleep, stress, legs feeling)
- Clean data: Remove spikes, dropouts, incorrect entries
